Posts.Content: Eula wrote: Hello, I am new to these discussions.  I have been diagnosed with invasive adenocarcinoma, ductal, grade 1, strongly positive estrogen receptor, negative progesterone receptor, HER2 protein expression 1+.  My knee-jerk reaction was I'm not that attached to that part of my body, take all you can to insure nothing is left to grow cancer.  A consultation with a local retired expert convinced me that lumpectomy w/radiation is as effective as the radical mastectomy. At a recent meeting with the radiology oncologist, he offered options-- the traditional whole breast radiation and the mammosite procedure.  He explained that the mammosite procedure is of much less duration, more concentrated to the site of the cancer and that studies to date indicate it is effective and lasts only one week.  The drawback is that it has been studied for only about 10 years and it is unknown what the next 15 or 20 years will bring.  The traditional whole breast radiology does seem to carry some potential risk of damage to the heart and/or lung (my cancer is on the left side).  To cut to the chase, I have to decide between these two options before surgery (10/3) and I am having difficulty with this choice.  I am 67 and don't know that the next 15 or so years is that significant.  The shorter duration appeals to me a lot.  Has anyone experienced this type (mammosite) of radiation therapy?  Also, has anyone undergone the aromatase inhibitor therapy and suffered significant bone loss as a result?  I just learned today that this is a downside to the current drugs used for this hormonal therapy.  Feedback will be appreciated.
